 ANNEX 1 ECUADOR PUBLIC ENTERPRISE REFORM TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECT A. Creating Institutional Capacity for Strategic Planning for Privatization and Divestiture of State enterprises in Ecuador I. Background 1. Privatization and divestiture have proceeded slowly but steadily in Ecuador. The privatization program has covered largely equity holdings in small enterprises, landholding and buildings. However, there has not been an over arching strategy for the privatization and divestiture of state enterprises. Nor has there been a strategic vision of future privatization or ways to incorporate the learning to date in one institution capable of giving a strategic vision for privatization and generating public support through clearly defined and transparent processes. As the country enters the next stage of privatization, divestiture and concession granting, such a vision will be crucial in order to undertake the larger transactions. Hence there is a clear need to provide such a capacity as the country goes ahead with the large privatizations such as in telecommunications and electricity. 2. Although the State Modernization Law, which was enacted in December 1993, established that the State Modernization Council was going to take the leadership for the strategic planning for privatization and divestiture of state enterprises in Ecuador, CONAM's institutional capacity remains to be built up. It currently lacks experienced technical staff to develop such a strategic vision and advise CONAM's management accordingly. CONAM's capacity to efficiently coordinate with other agencies involved in the state modernization process must also be developed. CONAM should be capable of maintaining the public informed about the government reform program but also of wining public confidence and support. Finally, CONAM should be capable of creating a consistent strategy among the different agencies charged with the responsibility for privatization, divestiture and granting of concessions. II. Institutional Support 3. To promote CONAM's strategic planning capacity, it is proposed to establish a small strategic planning unit staffed with consultants experienced in privatization and divestiture. They will work with the regular staff of CONAM on a daily basis, developing a strategic vision for privatization from a technical standpoint, bringing to the
 attention of CONAM's management emerging issues in privatization, and assisting the management in developing a strategic vision for privatization, divestiture and granting of concession. Such a vision would be disseminated widely to promote public awareness and support as well as guide other agencies involved in these activities. m. Consultants' Proriles and Tasks 4. Expertise is required in the following areas: (i) competition policy and regulatory aspects; (ii) legal aspects; and (iii) valuation and pricing aspects. 5. Competition and Regulatory Policy Analyst. The consultant should have a wide experience in competition policy and regulation in similar contexts to adapt the experience of other countries in order to create a competitive environment in Ecuador. The consultant will review the overall competition and regulatory provisions established in the Law of the Modernization of the State and determine the extent to which the underlying regulatory regime prevailing in a specific sector could be adopted for the privatization, divestiture and the granting of concessions in different sectors. The review of these environments across sectors would allow the formulation of an overall wide strategy promoting a competitive environment. 6. The consultant would be available to give technical advice in this area to other entities undertaking privatizations, divestiture and the granting of concessions. It is envisaged that the task will be completed after a period of two to three years, once that expertise is imparted to the staff of CONAM, and that the institution becomes adept at analyzing the strategic issues in competition and regulatory policies across the different sectors. 7. Legal Exper on Privatization, Divestiture and the Granting of Concessions. The consultant would have wide ranging experience with privatization, divestiture and granting of concessions on an inter-country basis. The consultant will need to be knowledgeable in the systemic law of the country as established by the Law of Modernization of the State, as well as the laws relating to different sectors at the transaction level. The consultant would need to give advice on the reconciliation of any conflicts between the overall laws and transaction related laws, recommend amendments to the laws when required and advice CONAM management on the refinement of the existing legal norms to bring about a competitive environment with transparent laws and implementable regulations to achieve privatization, divestiture and the granting of concession. The consultant will work closely with the competition policy and regulatory analyst and the staff of CONAM to ensure compatibility of the laws relating to
 - 3 - privatization, divestiture and the granting of concessions and provide the basis for a strategic vision for creating the proper competitive environment through laws and regulations. It is envisaged that the task will be completed after a period of 2 to 3 years. 8. Valuation and pricing specialist. The consultant will have wide inter-country, sector and transactions experience to value enterprises to be put up for sale, other forms of divestiture and to cost concessions. The consultant will provide a framework for such valuations taking into account the tax, regulatory and reporting practices prevailing in Ecuador and help facilitate transactions in a wide range of activities. The consultant will develop guidelines for the pre-qualification of bids based on the business plans provided by the potential buyers of enterprises and bidders for concessions. The consultant will need to evaluate the economic implications of different regulatory policies and advise CONAM's management and staff on the suitability of specific valuation methods, practices and conventions to ensure that the valuation and pricing process are established in a clear and transparent way. This would help to allay any accusations of unfair bids and cozy relationships between the sellers and the buyers. It is envisaged that the task will be completed after a period of 2 to 3 years. IV Strategic Planning Unit: Organization and Financing 9. The Strategic Planning Unit will be established within CONAM and report to the Director of CONAM. As indicated earlier, the consultants will be hired for a term which will not exceed three years. They will be financed under the project once their detailed Terms of Reference, biodata and contracts have been approved by the Bank. B. Guidelines for Privatization, Divestiture and Granting of Concessions I. Background 10. A common set of guidelines issued by a central agency charged with privatizations, divestiture and granting of concessions would contribute much to the coordination of these efforts that are currently dispersed among various agencies of government. There are two main reasons for the use of such guidelines. First, it is an essential element of transparency of the process. Second, to the extent that other agencies follow the guidelines, they will provide a common framework and help to increase competitive forces in the economy even among various sectors. Adherence to a set of guidelines would also make implementation easy across the country. It would help to provide a common regulatory environment, standardized methods of divestiture and make overall supervision of a privatization and concession granting program easier.
 - 4 - 11. Since the state enterprises that are to be privatized, divested or public services granted as concessions are in different sectors, it is not realistic for each and every case to follow every provision of the guidelines closely. Only the main principles need to be followed. In some cases, the actual privatization would follow a standard path as described in the guidelines. In other cases, the guidelines would only provide some principles. Nevertheless there is merit in developing a common set of guidelines and adopting them on a national basis. 12. CONAM is the agency that would issue such guidelines. It has a high powered board of directors, including a representative form the President's office, and it will have the technical expertise to issue and implement the guidelines. Towards that end, some broad guidelines are described below. These are related to the different stages of privatization, divestiture and the granting of concession. They follow the stages of a transaction - the identification of the privatization or divestiture program, preparation for sale or concession, actual sale or transfer and finally, safeguards to prevent changes in the regulatory environment following a privatization, divestiture or the graining of a concession. II. Guidelines. 13. The identification of enterprises for early privatization can be based on the tradeability of the activity in question. If the activity to be privatized is in a sector subject to international competition, that provides a ready made situation of competition. Small and medium size firms are easy to privatize as they or the sector in which they operate need not be restructured prior to privatization. They can be sold directly. 14. State owned enterprises in the non-tradeable sector, typically utilities, that have a natural monopoly character require the creation of a competitive environment through legal and regulatory changes as well as some restructuring. The form of transfer or ownership of function of a utility can be different, depending on each circumstance. Their large size, labor implications and high political profile makes the process more difficult, but necessary. The absence of such legal regulatory frameworks can reduce consumer welfare and diminish public support for privatization. 15. There are different ways to create efficiency. Changing ownership is only one, but the most powerful one to bring about efficiency. Other means could be used such as management contracts, leases, contracting out and concessions. However, these forms could contribute less to the reduction of the size of the State, an objective of the modernization of the State. Also, a possible problem with leasing and concession arrangements is that they may not provide sufficient incentives to maintain and expand the facilities in their charge. A private supplier that does not own the production facilities or is uncertain of contract renewal, may depreciate assets rapidly for short-run gain and skimp on routine maintenance.
 - 5 - 16. The primary aim of privatization is to increase efficiency and not to increase revenue. The sale of state owned companies in protected markets will detract from efficiency even though short run gains in revenue can be made. 17. Sale of state owned companies should be made on equal basis to both nationals and foreign purchasers as provided by the recent investment laws that give national status to foreign owned entities. Some discretion could prevail when the foreign purchaser is another state owned entity. Thus, a sale or granting of concessions must be on the basis of wide competition, both domestic and foreign. 18. In restructuring state enterprises for sale, large investments should be avoided, since there are greater risks involved in such a strategy. Instead, the important components of preparation for sale are carrying out legal, managerial and organization changes, financial workouts and labor shedding. 19. Labor can be co-opted to support the privatization and the granting of concessions by offer of shares. Some part of the shares could be retained earmarked for labor for later sale since the value of the remaining shares is expected to increase with the improvements in the regulatory environment, and with managerial and efficiency gains. Labor does not lose in privatization, if adequate attention is paid to the social cost of unemployment, through severance pay, unemployment benefits, retraining and job search assistance. 20. The best form of the sale is in an open market for cash. However, given the size of some sales, the limited development of the stock market and the difficulties of valuing assets in a changing regulatory, financial and legal environment, negotiated settlements, special financial arrangements and debt-equity swaps are available means to effect the sale. 21. All that is possible to do to increase transparency of the transaction must be done. This implies a large public information effort from the time a decision is made to privatize to the ultimate sale or the granting of concessions. 22. Efforts to improve the legal environment must go beyond the sale to ensure that the parties to the sale are legally bound to meet all the provisions of the agreement at the time of the sale. This would prevent the reversal of the agreement by either party to it.

INECEL's Organization and Management. INECEL faces internal administrative problems. The organization is headed by a Board with the features of a Council of Ministers. Decision-making tends to be slow and politically motivated. Furthermore, the current electricity law vests much power in the Board and little in the managing directors. Board meetings therefore tend to have an overcrowded agenda and little efficiency, since many items are sent back to be analyzed by informal study groups. Internally, INECEL lacks a management information system and has coordination problems among its six Directorates. The Quito offices are spread over 13 different locations, which has resulted in a duplication of administrative and financial staff, and in a slow information flow. 13. Control of Distribution companies. Distribution companies are not subject to Central Government restrictions. INECEL's control of its subsidiaries is weak, because the minority Board members appointed by regional organizations, unions, and local municipalities often assert a disproportionate weight in decision making, sometimes introducing political considerations. The largest distribution companies are EMELEC with about 38 percent of the country's final sales, and Empresa Electrica de Quito (EEQ) with about 26 percent. That leaves 17 distribution companies covering only 36 percent of total sales. The volume of sales and number of customers of some distribution
 - 11 - companies are thus limited and do not justify their existence. Reduction in their number could improve efficiency, service quality, and costs. 14. Staffing. The sector is overstaffed. In 1992, the labor productivity indicator measured as the number of customers per employee ratio was 152. Despite the significant improvement during the last decade (from 92 in 1980 to 152 in 1992), labor productivity is still low compared to that of more efficient utilities in Latin American countries (around 200). The sales per employee ratio has also increased, from 343 MWh in 1980 to 517 MWh in 1992, but this is also lower than the average for the region (906 MWh). The sector has about 10,475 employees, of which 2,475 correspond to INECEL and the remaining 8000 to the distribution companies. INECEL's staff composition also reveals serious distortions as the ratio between administrative and technical staff is about 2:1, excluding unskilled workers, which is high for a power sector utility. INECEL's authorities expect labor productivity to improve in the near future, as the Government has frozen the hiring of new staff and INECEL is studying a program to provide cash incentives for early retirement, but there is far less restraint on the growth of staff of the distribution companies which has steadily increased during the past decade. 15.  - 13 - II. MAIN SECTORAL AND POLICY ISSUES 19. The main issues of the power sector are: (a) a highly politicized approach to electricity price policy; (b) inadequate financial resources to support investment; (c) lack of independent roles of the State in the power sector as regulator and operator; and (d) lack of autonomy and accountability of the power utilities. Electricity Prices 20. The Electricity Law provides for prices to be set according to accounting principles, with an 8.5 percent return on revalued assets. Electricity prices are to be equitable nationwide; however, they have typically been based on political considerations. This system thus promotes inefficiencies. Although, electricity prices were sharply increased by 90 percent in October 1992, and 35 percent in June 1993, they are still below economic costs. This means INECEL will have to continue to rely on financial support from Government if prices are not increased by 24 percent in 1993 and 27 percent in 1994. Additionally, the price structure is inadequate, and residential consumers have been strongly subsidized by other types of customers. Finance 21. During the last decade, the sector's finances deteriorated due to low electricity prices that only covered sector operating and maintenance expenses. There is no external financing available for capital expansion projects during 1992 and 1993. Moreover, the Central Government's fiscal deficit severely limits Govemment financial support for new projects. INECEL does not collect electricity bills from distribution companies. As a result, reliability of electricity supply may deteriorate during the next five years and rural electrification projects may be curtailed. Legal and Regulatory Framework 22. The existing legal and regulatory framework, the current organization of the sector, and the state of the public utilities do not permit a rational improvement of the efficiency of the sector without a serious and sustained effort towards substantial reforms. Government intervention, political interference, and financial constraints have reduced the efficiency and productivity of the sector. The overall efficiency of the power sector is poor, characterized by INECEL's assumption of both regulatory and operational activities, inadequate corporate autonomy, low efficiency of public utilities, and inadequate pricing policies.
 - 14 - 23. The current legal framework does not encourage private participation in the sector. Corporate public utilities created by INECEL are mostly owned by the Government and are subject to the same monitoring and control system applied to public entities. Additionally, there is no clear definition on the future operation of EMELEC, whose concession expired in 1985. Private local and foreign investors are negotiating the purchase of EMELEC's shares, but the Government has not yet defined under what rules and conditions the concessions would be given to a new operator. INECEL's Autonomy. Management, and Accountability 24. INECEL is an integral part of the Central Government and fully subject to the same bureaucratic controls and restrictions as ministries, the Central Bank, the Secretariat of Development, the Office of the Controller General, and the General Procurement Office. It results in inefficiencies, slow acquisition of required goods, and a tendency to order more than required. Although, INECEL's subsidiaries are structured as corporations and are not subject to these controls, INECEL's control over subsidiary operations carries little weight due to political conditions and lack of expertise of INECEL's representatives on their board. III. PROPOSED REFORMS AND RECOMMENDATIONS 25. The Govemment's program to improve the efficiency and productivity of the power sector includes: (a) separation of state regulatory and commercial functions, concentrating on the regulatory function and gradually reducing its participation in operational business; (b) restructuring INECEL and its distribution companies; (c) setting prices based on economic cost; and (d) promoting the participation of private investors in generation and distribution activities. The thrust of this program has been agreed upon with Government as part of the preparation of a new electricity law, under the Bank Loan 2713-EC. These main reform lines were agreed upon with the MEM, CONAM and CONADE. Below are the basic principles of reform. 26. The reform objectives are to promote secure, timely, efficient and low cost supply of electricity, in particular to: (a) increase the efficiency of both private and public power companies as well as ensure the financial autonomy of the latter; (b) reduce the direct involvement of the Government in commercial power activities and increase the participation of private investors; (c) establish a transparent, stable and efficient procedure for regulating electricity prices within natural monopolies; and (d) protect the environment in all power activities. 27. The reform strategy consists of: (a) restructuring the legal and regulatory framework for the electricity sector, including the establishment of a central regulatory
 - 15 - agency, separating the Government's regulatory functions from its role as owner of public utilities; (b) restructuring INECEL and its subsidiary distribution companies, promoting decentralization and private participation; (c) establishing pricing policies and procedures, free from political and other interferences, which would reflect the economic cost of power production, transmission, distribution, and commercialization, and allowing for the financial soundness of well-run utilities; (d) promoting energy conservation through pricing and other measures; (e) revising the Electricity Law, so as to establish a concession regime for the private sector with defined service responsibilities and cancellation provisions in case of poor service or other violations of the laws and regulations, and establish transparent, stable and efficient rules for the calculation of electricity prices and their adjustment; (f) establishing appropriate regulations for protecting the environment in all electricity-related activities. Regulatory Framework 28. The national Electricity Law requires modification. A draft new Electricity Law has been prepared which redefines the role of the State in the power sector, clearly separating its policy/regulatory role from its role as owner of power public utility. 29. The draft Electricity Law supports the establishment of a regulatory agency aimed at: (a) approving tariff increases; (b) establishing clear rules regarding the right of private investors to obtain reasonable retums on their investments in the different sectoral segments (generation, transmission, and distribution levels); (c) establishing rules for price setting based on economic principles and clear mechanism for their adjustments; and (d) setting standards for and controlling the quality of service and for accounting and financial records of the utilities. The managing team will have a five year term assignment and they would be ineligible for public elective functions for a period of time after leaving the service. This agency should have strong power to supervise and regulate the sector. This Bill was submitted to Congress in June 1994 on a regular legislative basis. Congress' approval of the Bill is still pending. Tariffs 30. The proposed new Electricity Law modifies completely the existing tariff system moving from accounting to economic principles. Generation will be on a competitive basis and price of generated electricity will be set by market. Distribution companies and large customers will be free to negotiate long term contracts with generators. A secondary market coordinated by a National Dispatch Center will commercialize power in the short term following principles of marginal cost.
 - 16 - 31. Transmission charges will reflect average costs approved by the regulatory agency. Access to the transmission system will be open to all generating and distribution companies, as well as to any large customer willing to use the transmission network. 32. Distribution companies will charge a tariff defined at the bidding process for giving concession for services. Instead of existing accounting costs, tariff levels will be based on estimated cost for a standard utility having adequate efficiency and service quality. Institutional Framework 33. The proposed new structure of the power sector consists of the following: (a) Generation, Competition is introduced in the generation of electricity. No geographical concession area is defined for the generating companies. AU new generating concessions will be decided on a competitive basis. The distribution utilities will be free to contract power supply from the generation utility that offers the lowest electricity price. The power plants will be constructed and operated by private investors to sell energy to the distribution companies on a competitive basis. (b) Transmission. The existing transmission system will be vested with a sole company servicing all interconnected systems. This company will be owned by investors without any ownership rights in the generating and distribution companies to avoid hindering competition in the network. This company will charge a transmission tariff based on average cost per kWh transmitted in the system. It will allow free access to the system to all users. It will be responsible for investments in the transmission system. (c) Distnrbution. The distribution companies will operate in a partial monopoly scheme, responsible for supplying energy in their concession area. However, any large consumer will be allowed to contract energy directly from the producers. and use the distribution system with due payment for it. (d) National Dispatch Center (NDC). This center will define the economic dispatch of power generation aiming at minimizing the production costs and losses. The power market consists of: (a) a long-term market, in which participate producers, distributors and large industrial customers with negotiated contracts for supply of electricity; and (b) a short-term market, in which distributors buy power or energy in a spot market, i.e.
 - 17 - on an hourly or daily basis at a lower price than negotiated in the long- term market. Restructuring of INECEL 34. In accordance with the institutional framework proposed in the draft Electricity Law, INECEL will be restructured in smaller corporations. One transmission company, several generating companies and several distribution companies will result from this restructuring. The proposed law establishes a timetable for this restructuring to take place (twelve months after approval of the law), as well as for selling majority of their ownership to the private sector (30 months after approval). Private Investors 35. The Government plans to phase out its involvement in commercial activities in the sector and promote the participation of private investors in the electricity business. Doing so would alleviate sectoral competition for public funds. The proposed new Electricity Law enables participation of private investors as independent generators for implementing future thermal or hydro installations as well as distributors through currently owned by INECEL or new ones. Environment 36. This project will finance technical assistance, and therefore, no direct environmental effect will be created. However, in drafting the new institutional framework for the sector and in the technical assistance for possible privatization of assets, adequate environmental considerations and safeguards were taken. The proposed new Electricity Law establishes as a condition for granting concessions the approval by the Government of environmental studies to be submitted by future concessionaires. It also establishes that the regulatory agency will have the authority to enforce all environmental regulations to the power generating, transmission and distribution companies. The technical assistance for privatizing the existing installations will also include an environmental audit and the problems eventually found will have to be addressed by the new owner as a condition of the bidding process.

Empresa Estatal de Telecomunicaciones (EMETEL) provides local, long distance and international telephone and telex services to over 95 % of the subscribers. Additionally, Empresa Publica Municipal de Telefonos, Agua Potable y Alcantarillado (ETAPA), a corporation owned by the municipality of Cuenca, provides local telephone services in the city of Cuenca. Law 184 of August 10, 1992 separated the former Instituto Ecuatoriano de Telecomunicaciones (IETEL) into two entities: the operating functions were delegated to EMETEL, and the overall Sector supervision and control functions, including responsibility for allocation and control of the radio frequency spectrum, were assigned to the Superintendency of Telecommunications. Law 184 gave the Superintendency IETEL's frequency spectrum staff. However, it still has to recruit and train qualified staff to perform its new functions. Since Law 184 does not specify whether the Superintendency reports to the Executive or to the Legislative branch, this has created a vacuum of accountability, and the Government has had difficulty exercising its policy decisions. In addition to the public switched network, there are several dedicated private networks to meet the specialized requirements of private companies, public sector entitles in the petroleum and energy sectors, and the Armed Forces. Ecuador has no telecommunications manufacturing industry as such, although some ancillary equipment, such as small diameter subscriber cables, are produced locally. Access to Service" 2. With 550,000 direct exchange lines (DELs) in service, the average telephone density in Ecuador, is 4.9 direct exchange lines (DELs) per 100 inhabitants. This compares unfavorably with the averages for other Latin American countries (Colombia 7.4, Venezuela 8.5) and to the average for Latin America as a whole (7 DELs per 100 inhabitants). About 98% of all telephone lines are concentrated in urban areas. Quito and Guayaquil, with 28% of the country's population, had 77% of the DELs. Rural 1. Data as of December 31, 1993.
 - 27 - areas, with about 40% of the population, have only public call offices (PCOs) or no service. Nearly all DELs are served by automatic exchanges, with only 90 lines, in the rural areas, served from small manual exchanges. There are about 1,000 coin box telephones and public call offices. Automatic telex service is available to about 3,404 subscribers of whom about 88% were in Quito and Guayaquil. Usage of Service 3. Current statistics do not distinguish between residential and business telephones, nor is there data on the composition of traffic. However, since domestic call prices were unchanged for 30 years until 1989, the revenue from domestic (local and long distance) calls per DEL is a good indicator of the usage per line. International traffic has grown steadily in the past years, and it grew 22% in each of the years 1991 and 1992, while national traffic grew at a rate of 9% in the same period. Existing Facilities and Quality of Service 4. At end 1993, total telephone switching capacity was 912,000 lines and telex exchange capacity 7,380 lines. (This includes 30,000 lines of telephone switching capacity provided by ETAPA in Cuenca). Despite a large unmet demand, only about 63 % of the telephone exchange capacity is presently used. This is largely due to under- utilization of capacity of recently commissioned exchanges which have been placed in service ahead of expansion of the outside plant necessary to connect it to subscribers. 5. The quality of service is poor with many outages and long delays in restoration. Only 50% of faults are cleared within three days. Call completion rate is low averaging only 35 %. There is also severe congestion on many inter-urban routes during business hours when the call completion rate is practically zero. The poor quality of service is primarily due to (a) delayed rehabilitation and replacement of faulty or unserviceable equipment and cables: (b) equipment imbalance resulting from faulty planning and delayed investment: and (c) poor maintenance. About 20% of the exchange equipment needs replacement. Most of these old and obsolete exchanges are situated in the business areas and serve heavy traffic-generating subscribers. Equipment regrading is overdue in many of the older electromechanical exchanges. Redimensioning of exchanges and inter-exchange routes for efficient handling of traffic is also necessary. The cable network requires replacement in particular sections as well as rejoining where use of inadequate materials and improper splicing procedures has made the waterproofing ineffective. This is a particular problem in Guayaquil, where there is a sharp increase of cable faults during the rainy season. A recent survey of the Guayaquil network indicated that 20% of the primary and 50% of the secondary cable network needs to be replaced. This has affected service to about 50,000 subscribers. In addition, lack of free cable pairs and poor operational practices have often resulted in bypass of the congested secondary network and direct connection of the subscriber from primary cables. This,

doc.repnme: Ecuador - Public Enterprise Reform Technical Assistance Loan Project (PERTAL)
doc.abstracts: The major objectives of the Public Enterprise Reform Technical Assistance Loan Project are to support the Government's current efforts to: 1) reduce electricity subsidies in a sustainable way; 2) reform the legal and regulatory framework for the electricity and telecommunications sectors so as to ensure a complete separation of state policy and regulatory functions from commercial activities; 3) establish and/or strengthen the institutions in charge of the policy and regulatory functions which remain with Government; and 4) modify the legal status of the two state enterprises INECEL and EMETEL to prepare them for commercially oriented activity through concessions possibly combined with sale of assets or shares. To meet these objectives, the project will provide the Government with technical assistance in the form of consulting services and training to prepare the necessary legal, regulatory, institutional and sectoral reforms in the electricity and telecommunications sectors; define reform implementation; and prepare the privatization of specific activities whenever feasible.
